question.text: When a charged particle moving with velocity <math><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>v</mi> <mo stretchy="true">→</mo> </mover> </mrow> </math> is subjected to a magnetic field of induction <math> <mrow> <mover accent="true"> <mi>B</mi> <mo stretchy="true">→</mo> </mover> </mrow><mo>,</mo> </math> the force on it is non-zero. This implies that

options.text: angle between <math> <mrow>  <mover accent='true'>   <mi>v</mi>   <mo stretchy='true'>→</mo>  </mover>  </mrow></math> and <math> <mrow>  <mover accent='true'>   <mi>B</mi>   <mo stretchy='true'>→</mo>  </mover>  </mrow></math> is either zero or <math><mn>180</mn><mo>°</mo></math>

angle between <math> <mrow> <mover accent="true"> <mi>v</mi> <mo stretchy="true">→</mo> </mover> </mrow> </math> and <math> <mrow> <mover accent="true"> <mi>B</mi> <mo stretchy="true">→</mo> </mover> </mrow> </math> is necessarily <math><mn>90</mn><mo>°</mo></math>

angle between <math> <mrow> <mover accent="true"> <mi>v</mi> <mo stretchy="true">→</mo> </mover> </mrow> </math> and <math> <mrow> <mover accent="true"> <mi>B</mi> <mo stretchy="true">→</mo> </mover> </mrow> </math> can have any value other than <math><mn>90</mn><mo>°</mo></math>
